Frequently asked questions.
What is a Game Jam?
A Game Jam is an event where programmers, artists, storytellers musicians, and much more come together to create a game in a limited time. We're welcoming beginners and experts alike!
What is hacking? Is it safe?
No, we're not “hacking” bank accounts. Hacking is term for coding apps, games, websites etc. It's safe and entirely educational.
What can I make?
Anything related to games! You can make platformers, Sprig games, ARGs, board games. Your imagination is the limit! You can also make assets, music or design levels for games! At the end, we'll vote for each other projects and have prizes for the winners!
Do I need a team?
Nope! You'll have the opportunity to create your own team up to four. We can also put you in a team to meet new people. Find new friends, bring yours, or work alone.
What is Hack Club?
Hack Clubis a nonprofit global network (based in the U.S.) and network of student-led coding clubs & High school makers. Founded in 2014, Hack Clubs are now in nearly 400 high schools with 10,000 students each year.
What is AngelHacks?
AngelHacks started in 2019 has an in-person hacking (programming) event. This year, AngelHacks is Hack Club's offical Spring Event, all organized by high schoolers.
Who can participate in AngelHacks?
AngelHacks primarily targets high school / older middle school students. If you're outside of that range, we're looking for mentors and people to run workshops! If you're intrested, you can fill the form and let us know :)
What if I have never coded before?
At AngelHacks, complete beginners are not only welcome, but expected! Learn as you go with our workshops and mentors. A Game Jam isn't all about code, you can also create art, music, stories and more for games!
What do I need to bring?
You'll need your Student ID, laptop, a phone, chargers and anything else that you might need!
What's the event like? Is it safe?
There will be free food and refreshments. Workshops and activities will be held throughout the event. Adult supervision will be present at all times with access restricted to participants.
I have another question that'as not answered here!
Feel free to email us attoronto@angelhacks.orgor send us a message in #angelhacks-toronto on theHack Club Slack.
AngelHacks Toronto is an event crafted by Hack Clubbers.
Website open sourced athackclub/angelhacks-torontoand finances onHack Club Bank. You can read ourCode of Conducthere!

You are an expert in Hack Club topics related to Puttingthe“You”inCPU, From the beginning…Edit on GitHub.
Tell me about Intro | Putting the "You" in CPU

Curious exactly what happens when you run a program on your computer? Read this article to learn how multiprocessing works, what system calls really are, how computers manage memory with hardware interrupts, and how Linux loads executables.
ByLexi Mattick&Hack Club·
				July, 2023
I’ve donea lot of things with computers, but I’ve always had a gap in my knowledge: what exactly happens when you run a program on your computer? I thought about this gap — I had most of the requisite low-level knowledge, but I was struggling to piece everything together. Are programs really executing directly on the CPU, or is something else going on? I’ve used syscalls, but how do theywork? What are they, really? How do multiple programs run at the same time?
I cracked and started figuring as much out as possible. There aren’t many comprehensive systems resources if you aren’t going to college, so I had to sift through tons of different sources of varying quality and sometimes conflicting information. A couple weeks of research and almost 40 pages of notes later, I think I have a much better idea of how computers work from startup to program execution. I would’ve killed for one solid article explaining what I learned, so I’m writing the article that I wished I had.
And you know what they say… you only truly understand something if you can explain it to someone else.
In a hurry? Feel like you know this stuff already?
Read chapter 3and I guarantee you will learn something new. Unless you’re like, Linus Torvalds himself.
[This Space Intentionally Left Blank]
The bottom of every page is padded so readers can maintain a consistent eyeline.
Open source with ❤︎ on GitHub

Bridging the Gender Gap and Building the Future of Tech
General Interest Forms for the Spring 2025 semester will be out next week and the general interest meeting will be held in January at [redacted] makerspace in South Delhi or online via Zoom.REGISTRATION IS OPEN all year round on a rolling basis and it is completely free! All you need to become a member is:1. Be Female2. Be under the age of 19
Welcome to Hackerspace - Girls in Tech Club! We're an after-school program in New Delhi, India dedicated to introducing young women to the exciting world of technology. We cater towards middle-school / high-school-aged girls in particular and nudge them in the direction of STEM/tech.Accepting young girls at any skill level (be it beginners to advanced), we help girls become a part of the initiative through hands-on projects, mentorship, and collaborative learning. This is done by running coding workshops, building projects together, inviting mentors, asking questions and a whole lot of trial and error.We’re affiliated with Hack Club and host a lot of events focussed around their programs (like high seas, boba drops, etc.). We’re always looking for funding and your donations, be it monetary (even the smallest amount helps!) or in-kind (hardware components /  electronics kits/ spare laptops / discounts / gift cards)) would mean a lot to us and help those who we serve. We would love for those in the tech industry to donate your time to sit down for an AMA session and give us an idea of what it’s like working in the IT-sector specifically in India.

You are an expert in Hack Club topics related to Reference, Registers.
Tell me about Asmgame

Asmgameis a game that teaches you how to write assembly language. The game is based on the concept of a CPU with 3 registers and anaccumulator(which is like another register):A,B, and*A. The game is played by writing assembly language to solve puzzles. The game is designed to be a fun way to learn assembly language. For example, in the first puzzle, you need to write assembly code that swaps the values of theAandBregisters. One way to do this would be putting theAregister in to theaccumulator, putting the B register into the A register(and in doing so overwriting the previous value), and then putting theaccumulatorinto the B register. The game is designed to be a fun way to learn assembly language.

Tell me about HCB changelog

Which card is which? Is 6014 for this or that? Ugh. If you’re a member of multiple HCB organizations, it can be hard telling your cards apart.
I’ve started writing the organization name on the back of mine:

We’ve got a more elegant solution for you all, however. You can now customise the logo printed in the top right and we’ve started printing the organization name on the card:

(Apexis a high-altitude balloon-forcused hackathon running on HCB!)
Plus, we’ve got white cards now. Fancy.

It's that time of year again! We know you've been hard at work on your nonprofit projects, and we want to celebrate the achievements you've made in 2024. That's why we're excited to announce HCB Wrapped 2024, your year in review!

Check it out here:hcb.hackclub.com/wrapped
We hope you enjoy it. Happy holidays! 🎉
Note:You need to have access to the Google Workspace perk on HCB to use this feature
Have you ever needed to have multiple emails for your organization (like help@, sponsor@, [your name]@)?
Previously, you would have had to create a new account for each address, but you no longer need to.
On HCB, you can now create up to 30 aliases per Google Workspace account; all emails to an alias will be sent to its parent account's inbox. No more having to flip through 10 different inboxes!

Today we're launching a new way to stay up-to-date on HCB:our new blog.
For as long as I can remember, HCB has been usingHeadwayto announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.
With this change, all of our posts are now open source and available onGitHubas well.
We're excited to share more with you in the future. Stay tuned!
For a long time, HCB cards appeared as a mysterious, dark, unbranded card in your Apple Wallet.

Today, we're excited to announce that it's getting a new look! Some people might say it's fresh & crisp, just like a juicy apple 🍎. Enjoy!

Thanks to Ian and Sam for the design work!
Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:

To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know:

Are you trying to manually link your organization'saccount & routing numberswith a 3rd party service? Sometimes these services will ask for a bank account letter that proves you have access to your account number.
Luckily for you, sitting right on your documents page is averification letteryou can share. ✨✅
This handy one-pager allows organizations on HCB to prove they have access to their account & routing numbers.

Looking for a little bit of extra security? You can now turn on two-factor authentication for your account:

That'll prompt you for two authentication factors each time you log in, whether it's a hardware security key, a login code sent to your email/phone, or a time-based one time password.
You know what they say about 2FA, you may find it mildly annoying but baddies find it infuriating.Ok, no one says that but you get the point.
Are you a part of multiple organizations on HCB? Simply click on your organization's title to navigate between them! 🔥

Tell me about Counterspell

HACK CLUB'S BEGINNER FRIENDLY GAME JAM
NOVEMBER 23-24, 2024, IN 100+ CITIES
Counterspell is a beginner friendly game jam for high schoolers happening in 100+ cities simultaneously whereartists, musicians, and codersget together to build apps and games.
Build whatever you want!
Any game counts! The theme for Counterspell will be decided through peer voting before the event starts.
Whether you’re a beginner or experienced in programming- we’ll have workshops, resources and mentors throughout the 24 hours to help you with your project.
Artist, Musician or Coder?
Join one of threeguildswhen you sign up!
You can join the guild you identify with for exclusive swag and badges! You also get to compete against other guilds in friendly activities/challenges throughout Counterspell!
How does agame jamwork?
Sign up for a Counterspell Event in your city
Find a team of other teenagers at Counterspell
Start building your game (no experience needed)
Attend workshops, or talk to one of our mentors for help
Ship what you made and share it with the rest of the world!
Most Counterspell events will go on for24 hours(unless explicitly stated)
Here's a rough schedule so you know what to expect!

Counterspell is organized by teenagers, for teenagers.
See a city near you on the map?Sign up here!
FAQ
Am I eligible to sign up?
If you're 18 or under, yes, we are so excited to see you! If you're over 18 but
        still in high school, shoot us an email atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
Does participating cost anything?
It's entirely free! We'll have meals, snacks, and beverages onsite at the hackathon, as well as swag, prizes, and fun mini-events.
What has Hack Club done before?
We have run multiple events around the world. The summer of '21, wechartered a train across Americaand ran the world's longest hackathon on land. Last year, we ran an outdoors do-it-yourselfcamping 
        adventurein Cabot, Vermont.
I'm not good at coding, can I join?
This hackathon is for hackers of all skill levels! We'll have workshops and other events so join us and let's learn together. If you'd like to start exploring some introductory projects, check outHack Club Workshops.
What can I make at Counterspell?
At Counterspell, we're building video games of all kinds! The theme will be revealed at the start of the hackathon.
What do I need to bring to Counterspell?
Your laptop, charger, and an open mind! If your location is overnight, also bring toiletries, and a sleeping bag.
My parents are worried!
We're here to help! Ask them to reach out to us atcounterspell@hackclub.comand we'll make sure to answer all their questions!
How can I reach out for more questions?
Contact us! Reach out at#counterspellon the Hack Club Slack or email us atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
          We're always ready to answer all your questions!
Built with love by teenagers, for teenagers at Hack Club

Tell me about Low Skies | Hack Club

Low Skies
A three week event by Hack Club
Build stuff, battle others, get stuff!
Low Skies is free for teens to participate in, running Oct 3-24!
How this works:
Make cool projects!
Create personal projects and earn credit for your hours usingHackatime!
Battle against other projects!
After finishing your project, submit it toThe Keep! Your project will battle others in theThunderdome; winners getScales!
Get free tools and swag!
At theShoppe,you'llbe able to spend yourScaleson items of all sort, from Blahajs to Yubikeys!
One battle at a time, what will you make?
Build whatever you want!
Any technical project counts. You could build an AR game, pixel art display, drawing robot, and more! After you're done your project, submit it to The Keep! Your project will compete against other similar-timed projects and you'll earn Scales based on how well you do.
Don't know where to start?
Not sure what to make?
Here are some projects Hack Clubbers made over the summer:
Ajith (age 17) made a game where you canplay as a CPU!
Brendan (age 17) built an entire3D printerfrom scratch!
Shreyas (age 15) made anAudio Visualizer!
What's in stock?
Redeem these with your Scales! For high schoolers (or younger) only.
Pile of Stickers
Yubikey
Blahaj (friend)
Raspberry Pi Zero
Pinecil
iFixit Kit
Get the full list of items when you sign in!
FAQ
Who is eligible?
You need to be a high schooler (or younger). You just need aHackatimeaccount to participate. Different prizes have different country restrictions. Sign in with Hack Club Slack to get started!
How much does it cost?
100% free – all the prizes are donated to us or paid for by us! Some shipments may have customs charges that we can't cover depending on your country.
What types of projects count?
Projects need to be open source (ie. linked to a GitHub repo) & have a way for people to experience it (ie. a game, a website, etc).
How many projects can I build?
You can submit as many projects as you make. We count them after they've been finished!
I need help!
Contact us! Reach out in#low-skies-helpchannel of the Hack Club Slack. We're always ready to answer all your questions!
Does a team project count?
Not for this event! You must only enter projects that were built by yourself.
What about school work or a job?
Low Skies is about the joy of building for the sake of building. It must be a personal project! If you're building something for school or work, we can't count it.
Is this legit?
Yup! This summer, we ranArcade, a program that gave out similar prizes for free. We have also run multiple hackathons, including one on amoving train across Canadathis summer!
So, what are you waiting for?
Build. Battle. Repeat.
A project byHack Club.
Hack Club is a registered 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that supports a network of 20k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by building so we're creating community and providing grants so you can make. In the past few years, we'vepartnered with GitHub to run Arcade,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andran Canada's largest high school hackathon.

A hacker is often assumed as someone who tries to get unauthorized access to break into a system, but this isn't always true!
The term hacking in this case refers to the action of simply using one's technical knowledge to achieve a certain goal.

Tell me about Contribute to Hack Club

A list of activeHack Clubopen source repositories onGitHub
Hack Club is anonprofit network of high school coding clubs and makers around the
          world. The Hack Club community hasover 250 open source repositories, many
        of which are being actively developed every day. What makes these
        repositories open source is that they areeditable by the public, which encourages
        you, the Hack Club community, to come together and collaborate on code
        socially.
Transparency is a core value of Hack Club, and code is not the only
        thing we open source.Check out our finances, workshops, and more.
Wewelcome and encourage your contributions,
        and we look forward to seeing the things you create!
Looking to contribute but don't know how?We have you covered!
Use your web inspector to hack your way through a series of
                  challenges.
If you'renew here, scroll down for steps to
          get started!
Note: This guide assumes you have aGitHubaccount,gitset up on your machine, and atext editorfor editing the code.
This document contains a set of guidelines which any contributions
              to any Hack Club repository must follow.
Contributions can happen in a lot of ways. Addingissues, creatingpull requests,
              andreviewingexisting pull requests are a few of those ways.
A fork is a copy of a repository that you manage. Forks let you
              make changes to a project without affecting the original code. You
              can create this copy by clicking on the "Fork" button at the top
              right of the repository page.
Cloning a repository is how you download the repository's code to
              your computer. You can clone the repository by clicking the green
              "Code" button on the repository page.
Pull requests are how you suggest your code edits! The maintainers
              of the repository may comment on your pull request, ask for
              changes, or approve it right away and merge it in.
Congratulations, you're now anopen source contributor!
Hack Clubis a nonprofit network of high school coding clubs and makers around
            the world. We are so happy to have you!
We’ve got a 24/7 Slack chatroom of 25k+ teenagers learning to
                code & building amazing projects, & you’ll fit right in.
GitHub is a development platform where people collaborate on
                code. This is where we can find and edit each others code.
Pull requests are the way we edit each others code. Follow the
                link above for an interactive demonstation on how to make a pull
                request!
As a Hack Clubber, you are always learning and building things.
                Scrapbook allows you to share updates on the things you're doing
                with the rest of the Hack Club community.
Once you feel ready, you can start to contribute to other open
                source projects!

While assembling someSprigs, I realized a major problem with the Pi Pico Ws we used -they'rejust really expensive. So why settle?
And from this the Orpheus Pico was born, designed to be a drop-in open-source replacement to the Pi Pico with a ton of new features and some stylish Hack Club branding.
You can check out the features list if you want, but the tl;dr is:
I've had a lot of fun making it the way I wanted it to be, but now I want you to do the same. So go make something!

A BEGINNER FRIENDLY GAME JAM
NOVEMBER 23-24, 2024 • MANILA
Counterspell Manila is a beginner friendly game jam for high schoolers happening in Manila whereartists, musicians, and codersget together to build apps and games.
Build whatever you want!

Frequently Asked Questions
Am I eligible to sign up?
If you're 18 or under, yes, we are so excited to see you! If you're over 18 but
        still in high school, shoot us an email atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
Does participating cost anything?
It's entirely free! We'll have meals, snacks, and beverages onsite at the hackathon, as well as swag, prizes, and fun mini-events.
What has Hack Club done before?
We have run multiple events around the world. The summer of '21, wechartered a train across Americaand ran the world's longest hackathon on land. Last year, we ran an outdoors do-it-yourselfcamping 
        adventurein Cabot, Vermont.
I'm not good at coding, can I join?
This hackathon is for hackers of all skill levels! We'll have workshops and other events so join us and let's learn together. If you'd like to start exploring some introductory projects, check outHack Club Workshops.
What can I make at Counterspell?
At Counterspell, we're building video games of all kinds! The theme will be revealed at the start of the hackathon.
What do I need to bring to Counterspell?
Your laptop, charger, and an open mind! If your location is overnight, also bring toiletries, and a sleeping bag.
My parents are worried!
We're here to help! Ask them to reach out to us atcounterspell@hackclub.comand we'll make sure to answer all their questions!
How can I reach out for more questions?
Contact us! Reach out at#counterspellon the Hack Club Slack or email us atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
          We're always ready to answer all your questions!
Built with love by teenagers, for teenagers at Hack Club
Counterspell Manila Organizer:Carl Louise Romales (17, Manila)

Tell me about Hack Club STEM Egypt

Together, we utilize our expertise to build each other up to become better makers and hackers as a whole!
Develop your skills by building quirky, unique projects
Free sessions for everyone to participate and learn something new
Don't worry if you are new to programming; our seminars are highly beginner-friendly, and we are here to assist you at every step along the journey
Event
A hacker is not always someone who trespasses on banks or plunders a friend's V-Bucks. Hackers are individuals who identify problems that need to be solved and devise the most practical-efficient solutions. These issues frequently call for an inventive mentality, technological know-how, and exposure to new ideas. Many can be solved with computers or clever engineering. At STEM Egypt Hack Club, we want our hackers to be creative problem solvers who are also proficient in coding, engineering, and problem-solving.Coding and computer science not only apply to specific problems - it fundamentally teaches how to solve complex problems using step-by-step logic. Coding teaches you how to dissect the issues and find solutions, so knowing it is valuable regardless of the job you end up choosing. STEM Egypt Hack Club cards are mainly focused on coding and engineering, including building unique-new software projects, protecting the community's network, conducting research projects and articles and much more!
We have an official affiliation with the student organizationHack Club, which brings together like-minded makers, coders, and hackers on theSlackplatform. Numerous unique chances are provided by Hack Club, includingAMAswith well-known figures in the tech space, includingElon Musk,Gwen Shotwell,Patrick Collison, andTommy Devoss. Additionally, Hack Club hosts international coding competitions(in-person and online)that are a fantastic opportunity for students to bond and learn what it's like to hack in a
              group setting.
Here are the best projects and articles for the season!

HCB's donation page is a great way to raise money for your organization. With one click, you can share a link to your donation page on social media, in emails, or on your website. It's incredibly versatile, but how do you know which platforms perform best?
Starting today, you can analyze which website referred your donors, and, for more granular insights, theUTM parametersof the link they clicked. This data is available on the transaction details page for all donations with referrer data.
Hopefully this feature will help you understand where your donors are coming from and how to better reach them in the future!

I hope everyone has a wonderful holiday break and see you in the new year!
Today we're launching a new way to stay up-to-date on HCB: our new blog.
For as long as I can remember, HCB has been using Headway to announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.
With this change, all of our posts are now open source and available on GitHub as well.
We're excited to share more with you in the future. Stay tuned!
For a long time, HCB cards appeared as a mysterious, dark, unbranded card in your Apple Wallet.
Today, we're excited to announce that it's getting a new look! Some people might say it's fresh & crisp, just like a juicy apple 🍎. Enjoy!
Thanks to Ian and Sam for the design work!
Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:
To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
If you have any feedback on this wires feature, we'd love to hear from you! We're always looking to improve our product, and wires has been a difficult feature to polish.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know.
Hack Club launched High Seas! This is the largest Hack Club event ever, having already reached more than 1.5 million teenagers around the world. High Seas empowers teenagers to build projects, share them, and collectDoubloonswhich can be redeemed for amazing prizes.
Like all Hack Club initiatives, High Seas is open source and has transparent finances with HCB!
Until January 31st, we will send you free stuff just for coding. Here's how it works:
1. BUILD! Ship personal coding projects to earn Doubloons2. BATTLE! Ships compete for bonuses in peer-voted 1v1 matchups3. BOOTY! Exchange your Doubloons for cool stuff in the shop4. REPEAT! Build, battle, and booty it up until January 31st
To learn more and get involved, click here!
If you have feedback or feature requests, I'd love to hear them. Let me know your number one complaint about HCB by replying to this email.
All the best,
Dylan & the HCB Team

I’ve started writing the organization name on the back of mine:
We’ve got a more elegant solution for you all, however. You can now customise the logo printed in the top right and we’ve started printing the organization name on the card:
(Apexis a high-altitude balloon-forcused hackathon running on HCB!)

Have you ever needed to have multiple emails for your organization (like help@, sponsor@, [your name]@)?
Previously, you would have had to create a new account for each address, but you no longer need to.
On HCB, you can now create up to 30 aliases per Google Workspace account; all emails to an alias will be sent to its parent account's inbox. No more having to flip through 10 different inboxes!

We've put all the essential support links into a single support button at the bottom right of your screen. With just a click, you can contact us, leave feedback, or access our API docs and brand guidelines.
Also, be sure to visit our Help Center for tips, guides, and answers to FAQs---it's the best way to make the most of our features.
Transparency Mode has been one of HCB's flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. However, we've found that showcasing every transaction can sometimes mean extra housekeeping work for teams to keep the ledger tidy.
That's why we're excited to announce AI-powered memos for transactions!
Now, with 1-click, you can generate a transaction memo summarizing the receipt for any transaction. It's pretty simple:
Upload a receipt to a transaction.
Click the purple AI button to generate a memo.
Accept the suggestions by clicking the checkmark or pressing [enter].

You'll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt's contents.
As usual, we want to hear what you think!
As your fiscal sponsor, our mission is to empoweryour mission. This means helping you collect the donations that keep the lifeblood of your organization running.
As a result, we're introducing donations powered by Link. Link autofills your donors' payment details so they can easily complete their donation.
These simple, secure one-click payments are helping organizations grow their funds.
In addition to Link, we support Apple Pay, Google Pay, and good old-fashioned cards! 💳
All ACH transfers sent from HCB are now processed same-day!
That means, the moment an ACH is approved by HCB, it'll arrive that day (view the timing specifics). In most cases, this should cut the waiting time for an ACH from three business days to one.
You can now react to comments 😱! Show your thoughts instantly with a tap---whether it's a thumbs up, heart, or something else. Give it a try and add some fun to your conversations!

Exciting times are ahead for girls and nonbinary high school students at Hack Club.
Hack Club HQ is running four events in the next few months to empower girls and nonbinary students who code! All these events are running on HCB, using Transparency Mode. Each hackathon kicks off with a dinner featuring trailblazing women in tech.To learn more about these events and how to get involved, click here.
Golden hackathon, Bay Area, Sept 28th: workshops on Data Science, 3D Printing, and Web Development, with participants from Mission YoungArts, Home Away from Homelessness, and local schools.
Luna hackathon, New York City's Civic Hall, October 5th, with Girls Who Code on Web Development, Project Pitching, and Video Game Development with Sprig.
Celestial hackathon, Toronto, on October 19th at Shopify, will feature sessions on building PCBs, 3D modeling, and AI.
Ascend summit, Los Angeles, in mid-November, bringing together 50 girls and non-binary Hack Club leaders from around the world to code and meet mentors.

Transparency Mode has been one of HCB’s flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. However, we’ve found that showcasing every transaction can sometimes mean extra housekeeping work for teams to keep the ledger tidy.
That’s why we’re excited to announce AI-powered memos for transactions!
Now, with 1-click, you can generate a transaction memo summarizing the receipt for any transaction. It’s pretty simple:
You’ll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt’s contents.
As usual, we want to hear what you think!
There's nothing worse than checking for your card and realizing it's fallen out of your pocket. Now, when that happens, you can burn the card to cancel it and prevent any future transactions.
In the dark days of HCB, inviting people to your organization was always a binary risk assessment - "do I give this person unfettered access to everything, or nothing at all?"
Once we realized this was Suboptimal And A Bit Dangerous™️, we started to think about operational security from users' perspectives more carefully.
User roleswas step one. This introduced predetermined permission sets to control users' access in an organization.
Today,we're introducing spending controls. This allows managers of HCB organizations to impose a finer level of control on how much money a member can spend.
To get to a team member's spending controls page, visit the Team page and click on the$icon next to their name.
A team member's spending controls page gives you consolidated details of how they're using their cards.
When controls are disabled, a member can spend any amount of money with their cards. (Since they're not managers, so still can't transfer via ACH, check, HCB transfer, etc.)
With spending controls enabled, new transactions on Fiona's card will be approved/declined based on Fiona's balance. Since we haven't given her an allowance yet, her balance is zero! (as seen above)
Hint: click theNewbutton on the top right.
Now that I've given Fiona an allowance, she can spend it with her card! This $2,500 didn't leave the organization's balance when I created an allowance. Instead, both balances will decrease when she makes a purchase.
You should probably also know that these allowances are not time-dependent. They don't expire, and they do not recur (it's not a weekly/monthly limit).
As a convenience, you can also choose to enable spending controls and set an initial amount when you invite someone to your organization.

Hey folks - thanks for all great feedback on our recent reimbursements launch!
We’ve now made the peer review stage of the reimbursements flow optional. That means that you can choose whether or not other team members have to review a report submitted by a team member.
This setting can be found underReimbursementson your organization’s settings page.
Team reviews are still required for all reports submitted by external contributors.
👋 Hey everyone! Ever wanted to give out CUSTOM stickers for your organization/event? We're proud to announce that HCB has partnered with StickerNinja to offer all our fiscally sponsored organizations an exclusive 15% discount on sticker purchases made on their store!
This new perk can be found in the "Perks" tab of your HCB organization's dashboard. Send some custom stickers out into the 🌎!
Money’s great. If you’re reading this, you probably like money. Now, we’re making it easier than ever to get it.
Starting today, you can now process reimbursements for yourself, your team members, and your volunteers through HCB directly.
Looking to be reimbursed? Here's the process:
Compile a collection of expenses into a report on HCB.
Have your report reviewed by a team member and a HCB admin.
Get paid through ACH transfer or check.
You can try it out today in “Reimbursements” tab of your project.
Been using Expensify? We'll continue to process open reports; however, future reports should be made on HCB. We'll reach out soon with more details about offboarding from Expensify.
As your organization grows, so too does the number of people you invite to HCB. Today, we're handing you the keys to lock down critical actions to your most trusted team members.
When managing your team on HCB, you now have the choice of assigning users one of two roles:managerormember.
Managerscan do everything, just like everyone could before. This includes actions like editing your organization's settings, managing other users, and sending money (ACH, Check, HCB transfer, etc.).
Membershave limited permissions, but they can still spend money using their HCB card.
Our goal is to enhance security and provide you with the tools to grow your organization. Take it for a test drive by enabling the User Roles feature preview in your organization's settings. To learn more, see therolespage.
This feature has been highly requested, and we want to get it right. If you have feedback, please file it in the box at the bottom right of HCB.

We at Hack Club HQ love to fill our HCB account's ledger with emojis and custom memos for each transaction. Recently, however, we've been falling behind due to the volume of transactions on the account.
Today, we've added a new feature preview ("Rename Transactions on the Ledger") that'll make renaming transactions a lot faster. The holidays are coming up and we know many of you are trying to keep yourselves off the accountants’ naughty list. And that means uploading receipts! To aid you in your recordkeeping endeavors, we’re launching a brand new feature: Receipt Bin.
Receipt Bin allows you to upload your receipts now and worry about them later. Rather than scrambling to upload the receipt to the right transaction, you can just text it or email it to us. We’ll hang onto them for you and will try to suggest which transaction they belong to. You can then swing by the new-and-improved Receipt Center at any time to link the receipts from your Receipt Bin to their corresponding transaction.
Text(864) 548-HACKor head tothe settings page‬to get started today!
Starting today, in addition to a CSV or JSON file, you can now export your transaction into a Ledger file for use with theLedger CLI.
You may be wondering, what's the backstory behind Ledger? Five years ago, Hack Club HQ used Ledger to keep track of and open source all it's finances:https://github.com/hackclub/ledger. It became too much to maintain. When HQ itself began using HCB, we built Transparency Mode so that we could continue open sourcing our finances. That said, Ledger still is awesome. So now, if you'd like to use the Ledger CLI and are on HCB, you can export your transactions to the.ledgerfile format and have fun exploring your money in the terminal!
Additionally, you can also export the transactions of organisations with Transparency Mode enabled, check out HQ's finances:https://hcb.hackclub.com/exports/hq.ledger.
Hey folks! We've got two brand new bits of info to share with you all. First, Hack Club Bank isgrowing— we just hit 💸 $10,000,000 💸 in total transactions for fiscally sponsored organizations! Go you! (and this doesn't even include Hack Club's money!)
Second bit of news: the government has some rules about who can— and cannot— call themselves a bank. Now that we've grown a LOT, it's time to change the way we refer to ourselves. As of today,we're shortening our name to HCB.
To celebrate, here are 10 acronyms for HCB:
We can now be found athcb.hackclub.com,hackclub.com/hcb,hcb@hackclub.com, and so on. Not to fret, though; all of your old links will redirect, and we can still be reached at our old email.
We're still the same ol' fiscal sponsor you know and love, just with a few fewer letters.New name, same great taste!
Tired of having transactions declined because you accidentally put in your address instead of ours? Now you can edit your billing address (and update payment information accordingly) wherever you Bank!

Say goodbye to baring the heavy prestige of Fiona Hackworth III, and just be known as Fiona!
While we are required to collect legal names for compliance, most places on Hack Club Bank will now just show your preferred name (if set).
Go to your settings and set your preferred name today!

Hi HCB users! Has it been your lifelong dream to use Google Workspace? ☁️ Have you ever wanted to make your emails even more awesome with the flair of a custom domain? Well, now you can - we're relaunching the Google Workspace perk! 🎉
Head on over to your org on Bank, and you'll find that there's now a Google Workspace tab in the sidebar where you can join the waitlist!


Once you've filled out the form, we'll get back to you within the next 48 hours to let you know if you're approved for one of our open slots.
Unfortunately, we still only have a set limit of slots for access from Google to distribute, but we have systems in place now that will open these up more frequently.
💰 P.S. Orgs with donor funding will be prioritized for open slots.
Now, when you share links from Hack Club Bank on social media or messaging apps, you'll see a preview image accompanying the link, providing the world with an eye-catching window into your organization’s finances.

At Hack Club Bank, pushing for financial transparency is one of our primary goals. Social media preview images are a small touch that make your finances more shareable and clickable across the web.
Try it out today by enablingTransparency Mode, and enjoy the refreshed visual appeal of sharing your finances!
HCB prides itself on being at the cutting edge of banking technology. But some parts of the financial system are a little... less cutting-edge.

We want to support those systems too, so now, you candeposit checks directly into your Hack Club Bank accountby just taking a photo! Just snap a picture, wait a day or two, and watch the funds roll into your account.

This feature is available now for everyone. Go write yourself a check and deposit it right now, I dare you!

This just in: Hack Club Bank accounts now have account/routing numbers, which means you can receive payouts from platforms like Shopify and Venmo!
Here are some cool things you can do with account numbers:
You can receive money from any platform that asks for an account/routing number. For security, your account number is deposit-only: you can't withdraw money using it.
This is live for everyone right now— check out the new "Account/routing number" page in your sidebar and start receiving money!

Fundraising for your nonprofit or hackathon is hard, and takes time away from actually using the donated money. What if the funds could raise themselves?
To fix this, I added a monthly subscription option to your organization's donation page— now when a donor sends a payment, they can opt-in to make their donation monthly. No more manually sending invoices every month.

Here'smy own org'smonthly donation page!
This feature is live for everyone right now— you don't need to opt-in. You can see your recurring donors in your dashboard's Donations tab:

Hope this helps you spend less time fundraising, and more time doing whatever it is your nonprofit does.
As of today you can test out a new preview feature:SMS notifications when you swipe your card.
Emails aren't always immediate, and when you're dashing through the checkout line at Costco while stocking up on breakfast for your hackathon 2 minutes could be the difference between remembering to take a photo of your receipt or  throwing it away entirely.
Now with SMS notifications, you'll get this:

When you use your card in-person, you'll get a text with a link to upload your receipt. You can opt-in to the feature preview from yourfeature previewspage.
In the future we can add the ability to reply directly to the text with a photo of your receipt.
You can name your card to help keep everything organized (eg. General Spending, Online Retailers, Amazon). Renameyour cardsby clicking on the edit name button when viewing your card.

Your homepage is now a bit more customizable— if you're a member of several organizations on Bank, you can now change their order just by dragging them around!

Hey all! Today hackathon grants are live.
In case you missed it, we’re distributing $500 grants for IRL high school hackathons with the help ofFIRST.
If you're planning to run your own,check it out.
Additionally, we’re waiving the 7% fee for IRL high school hackathons until Dec 31st. That means any funds you raise between now and then are fee-free! You can check your fee status on your event’s settings page.

Renaming transactions is a great way to organize your finances on Hack Club Bank. It also helps team members and supporters to understand how your organization's money is spent. Upon renaming a transaction, you'll now be provided with a dropdown list of suggestions based on similar, previous transactions in your transaction history!

Donations and invoices now deposit in the time it takes for you to read this sentence.
With many financial systems, money can take up to two weeks to move. But now on Hack Club Bank, gone are the days when you had to wait. Behind the scenes, we will seamlessly loan you the incoming funds.
The money will be ✨ instantly ✨ available for your pizza buying needs!

Hey fellow Bankers!
Every event needs a great venue and with a great venue comes insurance requirements... but where do you start?! A Google search lands you so many options and probably more questions than when you started...

Partnering withThe Event Helper, we’ve created a streamlined process for you to purchase event insurance on Bank without the hassle. You now have access to a simplified, custom form in your “Perks” tab, and once submitted, Bank team will provide you with a custom quote. All of the costs are directly from The Event Helper – we don't charge a fee on top!
We're excited to share that Hack Club Bank now has an official public API.
TheHack Club Bank APIis a read-only, unauthenticated REST API which enables you to read public information from organizations withTransparency Modeenabled. This includes transaction history like checks, ACHs, invoices, transfers, donations, as well as organizations and their respective team members.
This API will pave the way for more applications likeSlack Club Bank,HackPenn's financial visualization, and your next amazing project. We can't wait to see what you ship!

If you run into any bugs or have any feedback, please let us know at bank@hackclub.com!
— Ella, Caleb, and Gary
Have you ever wanted to change your organization's URL? Previously this was a dangerous affair; bookmarks to the old URL would just stop working, including your donation page.
Now, we'llautomatically redirect your old URL to your new one! It's like magic.
You can change your organization's URL by clicking "Settings" in the sidebar. Happy hacking!

Starting today, Hack Club Bank will be sending out seasonal newsletters to share about new features, transparent orgs, and other awesome announcements. 🎉 Feel free toreach out to meif you didn't receive the summer edition and would like to be added!

The financial system in the US isa little slow. In personal finance, that's annoying. For a hackathon organizer who needs tobuy50+burritoswhile herding ~~cats~~ attendees & dodging taxis in NYC, slow money transfers is too much.
As of todaywe've improved our account transfers beta to instantly add to your balance.
Donations usually take 3-5 days from a donor swiping their card to finally arriving in your account. Hackathon organizers often zero out their balance while waiting for a donation payment to arrive.
You can nowrequest afrontfor paid funds that are still in transit– if your event is happening within 7 days we'll lend you the funds viaan  instant transfer from us, to you. Once the event is over we'll transfer the funds back out of your account.
Eligible invoices and donations have a button to request a front:

Keep in mind we can only front funds that we can confirm paid (ie. they swiped their card successfully, but the funds haven't arrived yet), and we may take up to 24 hours to get your request. Although we're focusing on hackathons running within 7 days, we know everyone has a different story. If you have a special circumstance, please reach out– we are happy to talk through it with you.
p.s. Users who enabled theaccount transfer betawill also find their transfers reflect in their budgets immediately, instead of the 3-4 days that it used to take.
Little update to the donation form: donors can now contribute to your project using Apple Pay! This feature is now available to all organizations running on Hack Club Bank.

Today we're shipping 3 major improvements to the receipt uploading experience on Hack Club Bank!
Your receipts pageis now smarter– just click "Add a receipt" or drag & drop a file to instantly attach your receipt. We've also fixed a bug that caused declined & refunded transactions to show up, even though they don't need receipts.The transaction details page has drag & drop, too– just drop a file anywhere to upload a receipt to that transaction.
In a busy checkout line? The “upload a receipt” link we email you has been totally redesigned for mobile, with the ability to take photos of your receipt directly from the page. If you’re uploading from a tablet or laptop, drag-and-drop is also supported.
Finally, you don’t even have to open Bank– now you can reply to the “upload a receipt” emails with a photo or PDF of your receipt. This is especially useful if you have limited bandwidth and can't load the site.
What's next– receipt upload via direct brain connection? We'd love to hear your ideas, both for receipts and other features– be sure to leave us your feedback in Slack or via the Bank interface!

– Caleb and Max
A feature preview is live for users to try out:transfers between HCB accounts.
People who are on multiple teams (ie. running a hackathon and running a club with separate accounts) can manage their money across accounts on Hack Club Bank.

Previously users would have to invoice themselves to move funds. Besides the 7% fee on those funds, it would take between 5-7 days for funds to show up.Transfers cut the time in half and changes "fee" to "free".
You can enable the betain your account settings. Please send me your feedback!
A new feature preview is available for users to opt-into. Once enabled, you can reply to the automated "upload your receipt" emails with your receipt directly– no need to click any links.

You can enable the previewin your account settings. Please send me your feedback!

Few things are as essential to the banking experience as photo IDs. You always gotta wait for the teller to get a real good look at you, and your ID, before making a transaction. (after all, you wouldn't want your near-identical evil twin stealing your hard-earned money)
The Hack Club Bank experience should feel as good or better than a physical IRL bank. Now,you can sign in using just your face (or fingerprint), on supported devices & browsers.

Currently, this includes modern versions ofGoogle Chrome,Safari, andEdge(as well assomeversionsof Firefox), but you can check for support on your current deviceusing this nifty website.
Have a Yubikey? Guess what: Bank supports hardware security keys too!
To get set up, head on down to the brand newSecurity Keyssection of your Bank settings. You'll be enjoying faster sign-ins in no time!
I hate passwords. I can neverremember them when I need them, each new account I create means another'unique' password, andpeople are great at leaking them. Wereallydon't want to burden everyone with all that just to access their financial platform, so now it's even easier to login to Hack Club Bank without a password.
I'm happy to announce thatyou can now get login codes for Hack Club Bank via SMS.The feature can be enabled fromyour settings page.

Users on iPhone and some Android phones can autofill their SMS login code.
You can now get your passwordless login code that much faster– reducing login on some devices down to under 10 seconds.
This post is to explain the background details of our switch to Stripe Issuing. Accounts that need action to make the switch will receive an email.
Emburse cards have been a feature since one of the earliest versions of Hack Club Bank, allowing any team member to spend money with a debit card without dealing with reimbursements. While that’s been amazing, there have been a few trade-offs with using Emburse:
These trade-offs made sense when we first started, but lots of details have changed in the last 2 years. Hack Club Bank has grown by…I started doing the math on this, but the comparison is stupid–our first year on Emburse has less than $1k spent per month, last week Bank users spent $20k through their cards. Emburse has been acquired (by a company that renamed to Emburse) & have shifted their product features.
Recently Emburse announced they’d be removing the card budgeting feature Bank currently relies on. If we stayed on Emburse the new flow would require organizers to request funds for a purchase, staff (Michael / Chaleb) to approve the purchase amount, then the card could make the transaction. Emburse was super gracious about the change, delaying the budget feature removal long enough for us to switch to another platform.
The card alternative we’ve eyed for awhile is Stripe Issuing, but it was in private beta we couldn’t access when we built Hack Club Bank. At the time of writing, we’ve got a private version of Stripe Issuing cards running on Hack Club Bank (only available to admins) to make sure our new system works. I’m happy to say it improves many of the previous issues with cards:
This is obviously a big change, and if you have any questions/comments please let us know either by reaching out to bank@hackclub.com or posting in the#bankchannel on Slack.
4 major improvements to Bank live today:
All of this is live for everyone now. More to come! 👀
Thanks to our generous friends over at repl.it, in light of COVID-19,Hack Club Bank users get a free Hacker plan for the next year. Repl.it is an amazing web IDE, where you can get basically any programming language running in your web browser in just a few seconds—regardless of what kind of computer you have. The Hacker plan, normally $84, gives you private projects, unlimited collaborators, & unlimited storage. They’ve generously sponsored many events that have run on Hack Club Bank, and we’re so thankful for their continued support.
To claim your subscription, visit the promo page & click "Apply". It’s limited to the first 500 people who claim it, so don’t wait.
Hope you’re safe & well. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to reply & ask away!
Last week, we launched a new feature in Hack Club Bank:Transparency Mode.
With Transparency Mode, you can open source your finances instantly from your account settings page. Why would you want to do that? Nonprofit donors deserve to know what their contributions are funding—as a hackathon/nonprofit, you can talk about what you’re spending money on, but transparency in every transaction builds trust for supporters. It’s already live in action!
That’s not all. When Hack Club first started, Zach’s hope was to build a different kind of organization: one not only open source with code, but open source with its finances too. Every month, Zach would painstaking put every transactionon GitHub. Unfortunately, as we grew, the tooling took too long & we had to outsource our books to an accounting firm that didn’t know what GitHub was.
We’ll be sharing this publicly next week, but Bank users are getting a sneak peek today:Hack Club HQ has been running entirely on Bank for months now, and our finances are public. Dig in, right here:bank.hackclub.com/hq.
Let’s set a new standard in financial transparency for nonprofits. If you have any questions or feedback on how to improve Transparency Mode, please let us (bank@hackclub.com) know!

Starting today, there's no longer a fee for accepting credit cards, bank transfers, or any other payment method.
You've invoiced Balsamiq for $500, they paid via credit card, but you only received $485.20. Where'd that $14.80 go? Welcome to the world of payment processing. (HC Bank usesStripe)
Payment processing fees are annoying. Calculating them ahead of time is frustrating and the result is alwayslessmoney for your event, club, or project.
Starting today, Hack Club Bank will make all your payment processing fees disappear.
This means that regardless of whether a sponsor is paying via credit card, ACH, or wire, when you send an invoice for $500, you'll receive $500.
And we're taking it even further.
I'm proud to share we're also reimbursing all previous payment processing fees, from all time, for everyone.
Depending on the size of past invoices, you'll receive somewhere between $4.48 and $390.50 (actual numbers) granted to your HC Bank account this week.
If you want to read more, check out ourblog post with the full story.
P.S. We also resigned the invoice page to show you way more details.

Sprig is a gaming console built by members of HC - it's built with the Raspberry Pi Pico (https://www.raspberrypi.com/products/raspberry-pi-pico/) and anybody who builds a game for it can get a console, which you can use to play games on or repurpose and take apart! Tell me about Blossom: Atlanta's Day of Service

Blossom is agender-focused hackathon(social coding event) open to all Girl Scouts! We welcome you come together for a day to discover the joy of code, build awesome projects, and share them with one another.
In this workshop, participants will learn the fundamentals of circuit board design with Hack Club's OnBoard program. They’ll use EasyEDA, a free circuit design software, to complete this. With this track, attendees will learn to use that software as well as the basics of PCB design. As a bonus, after students complete this track, they’ll be shipped their PCB to have a physical copy of their creation!
In this workshop, participants will learn to create computer-generated art by drawing a flower (or squares or a tree). They’ll use Blot, a robotic arm created by Hack Club that translates code to creation. With this track, attendees will learn JavaScript and digital fabrication. After students complete this track, they’ll be shipped their own robot arm to draw out their creation!
Yes! Blossom is beginner-friendly, and we’ll be holding workshops to get you started building your first coding projects.
A hackathon is asocial coding event-- you get a full day, mentors and workshops, and lots of food and swag to build anything you want. Even if you've never written a line of code before, we'd love to have you there!
You can find us in the #blossom channel on Hack Club Slack, or email us atsahiti@hackclub.com.
🌸 This website is open source athackclub/blossom.

I finished my saxophone MIDI controller 🎷! It lets you play any software instrument you’d like using saxophone fingerings, allowing you to practice without disturbing others, create music in any DAW, and perform with it. Check it out athttps://github.com/Whackalenso/CircuitSax
@samuel
Just fixed some final bugs to ship the mobile app for Back on Track America, a nonprofit organization dedicated to serving the homeless and those suffering from food insecurity by coordinating student volunteers in several communities. The app allows volunteers to sign up for their location, receive announcements from location leaders, and discuss upcoming events! ⚒️ It's built with React Native & NativeWind on the frontend, and using Pocketbase on the backend. It's also now being submitted for#cider, so that it can get published on the app store! An android build on the play store is also coming soon. Check out the code at https://github.com/backontrackus/app and https://github.com/backontrackus/backend
FAQ
Who is eligible?
You need to be a high schooler (or younger).
How much does it cost?
100% free - all the prizes are donated to us or paid for by us!
What types of projects count?
Anything that you've programmed and is open-source!
How many projects can I build?
All the projects! The land's the limit! (But seriously, you could build as many as you want.)
I need help!
Read the bigFAQ. Still stuck? Reach out in#high-seas-helpchannel of the Hack Club Slack and we'll help you out!
Does school work or a job count?
High Seas is about the joy of building for the sake of building. If you're building something for school or work, we can't count it.
Is this legit?
Yup! This summer, we ranArcade, which gave out similar prizes for working on personal projects.

Tell me about Editor | Sprig

Sprig is a tiny construction kit to build tile based games.
The games are written in JavaScript.
It was made by Hack Club, a global community of teen coders who
believe people learn best by making things they care about
and sharing them with others. You can watchthis videofor an introduction to Sprig website.
Run games by hitting theRunbutton or pressingShift+Enter.
If this is your first time using Sprig, try playing through thetutorial. From there, we suggest hacking on any of thecurrent gamesor starting from scratch.
If you ever need help, have ideas, or want to meet other game-makers, join the community in the#sprigchannel on theHack Club Slack.
Sprig games are made up of grids of square tiles.
Tell Sprig what types of sprites are available in your game.
Bitmap keys must be a single character.
We recommend storing character keys in variables.
To create a new bitmap, type
Those are backticks! Click on the highlighted “bitmap” button to edit your drawing.
The order of sprite types in your legend also determines the z-order of drawing them. Sprite types that come first are drawn on top.
Tiles a bitmap as the background of the game:
This only changes the visuals of the game.
Designing a level is like drawing a bitmap:
The characters in the map come from the order of your bitmap legend.
Levels don’t have to be kept track of in a legend, you should store them in a variable yourself.
You can callsetMapto clear the game and load a new level:
You might want to keep track of multiple levels using an array to switch between them mid-game:
Solid sprites can’t overlap with each other.
This is useful for creating things like walls:
UsesetPushablesto make sprites push other sprites around. The sprite on the left will be able to push all sprites listed on the right.
Watch out!Make sure everything you pass tosetPushablesis also marked as a solid or they won’t be pushed around.
Get the width of the current map.
Get the height of the current map.
Sprig has eight inputsw,a,s,d,i,j,k,l.
Typicallyw,a,s,dare used as directional controls.
Do something when the player presses a control:
Runs after every input event has finished being handled. Useful for tasks like checking win states:
Each tile can contain any number of sprites stacked on top of each other.
Sprites contain:
You can move the sprite by settingxandy.
ThebitmapKeycan also be changed to update the rendered graphic and collision rules the sprite will follow.
You can remove a sprite withsprite.remove().
Returns a list of the sprites in the specified tile.
Returns a list of the tiles that contain type.
tilesWithaccepts multiple sprite types.
Creates a new sprite of the given type.
Removes all sprites from the specified tile.
Returns all sprites of the given type.
If no bitmap key is specified, it returns all the sprites in the game.
Returns the first sprite of a given type.
Useful if you know there’s only one of a sprite, such as with a player character.
Shortcut forgetAll(type)[0].
You can add text with optionalx,y, andcolor.
In Sprig, each color is represented by a single character. Likebitmapandmap, you can use thecolorkeyword to pick a color for your text. A preview of your selected color will also show next to the character.
For example:
Clears all text on the screen.
Sprig comes bundled with a built-in sound engine and sequencer! You can use this to write background music, or with a high BPM to make sound effects.
You can create a tune with thetunekeyword.
As usual, click on the button to open an editor window.

You are an expert in Hack Club topics related to LGB Hack Club:Inspiring the next generation of programmers, Hack Club is a global community of over 36,550 teens.
Tell me about LGB Hack Club

Fill out the form to join the club! It's not an application, just a way for us to know how many people are interested.
Hack Club is not about hacking, it's about learning to code and building things. Hack Club is a global network of programming clubs where members learn to code through tinkering and building projects. Learn more athackclub.com.
Take a look at the projects & lessons you can take part in this year.
Basic Coding
Learn the basics of programming in languages such as Python, JavaScript, and more. Even if you're not an expert when the part ends, we want to give you the confidence to code and build projects with us and on your own.

GLaDOS
Continue working on the life-sized GLaDOS replica that we started last year. We will be working on the AI, the voice, and the movement of the robot based on facial recognition.

STEM Show?
Even though GLaDOS was presented last year, we willhopefullybe able to present it this year at the STEM Show. We will be showcasing the AI, the voice, and the movement of the robot.

Take a deeper look at the star of the show, GLaDOS.
GLaDOS is a sarcastic, artificial intelligence computer system that appears in the video games Portal and Portal 2. Portal is a video game series where the player solves puzzles using a portal gun to create portals on surfaces. GLaDOS is the main antagonist of the series.
                Last year, the Advanced Coding and Robotics ECA group(member list)built a life-sized replica of GLaDOS. The robot was built using a 3D printer and programmed to sustain a conversation with a person. It was featured in the STEM Show last year and was a hit among the audience. Its biggest accomplishment was attending theAI for Good Global Summitat the Ecolint booth.

Image byITU Pictures, taken by S. Jacobson-Walsh, used underCC BY-NC-SA 2.0. Original source:here.
Learn over 5 programming languages
Work and complete over 3 projects
Infinite possibilities
Take a look at the plan for this year.
Introduction:Everyone will introduce themselves and talk a little bit about why they joined the club. Then, the club leaders will speak a bit more about Hack Club and what they do.
Basics of Programming:Learn the basics of programming in languages such as Python, JavaScript, and more. We do this to give you the confidence to code and build projects with us and on your own.
Start Building:We'll start working on GLaDOS, improving the code and the robot itself!
Present:We hope to present GLaDOS at the STEM Show this year.
Want to learn more or have a question? Contact us!

Golden is a social coding event open to female and nonbinary students. We welcome all high school programmers, artists, dreamers, creators to join us for a day of building, exploring, and sharing.

Tell me about HCB Blog

HCB's donation page is a great way to raise money for your organization. With one click, you can share a link to your donation page on social media, in emails, or on your website. It's incredibly versatile, but how do you know which platforms perform best?
Starting today, you can analyze which website referred your donors, and, for more granular insights, theUTM parametersof the link they clicked. This data is available on the transaction details page for all donations with referrer data.
Hopefully this feature will help you understand where your donors are coming from and how to better reach them in the future!

Today we're launching a new way to stay up-to-date on HCB: our new blog.
For as long as I can remember, HCB has been using Headway to announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.
With this change, all of our posts are now open source and available on GitHub as well.
We're excited to share more with you in the future. Stay tuned!
For a long time, HCB cards appeared as a mysterious, dark, unbranded card in your Apple Wallet.
Today, we're excited to announce that it's getting a new look! Some people might say it's fresh & crisp, just like a juicy apple 🍎. Enjoy!
Thanks to Ian and Sam for the design work!
Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:
To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
If you have any feedback on this wires feature, we'd love to hear from you! We're always looking to improve our product, and wires has been a difficult feature to polish.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know.
Hack Club launched High Seas! This is the largest Hack Club event ever, having already reached more than 1.5 million teenagers around the world. High Seas empowers teenagers to build projects, share them, and collectDoubloonswhich can be redeemed for amazing prizes.
Like all Hack Club initiatives, High Seas is open source and has transparent finances with HCB!
Until January 31st, we will send you free stuff just for coding. Here's how it works:
1. BUILD! Ship personal coding projects to earn Doubloons2. BATTLE! Ships compete for bonuses in peer-voted 1v1 matchups3. BOOTY! Exchange your Doubloons for cool stuff in the shop4. REPEAT! Build, battle, and booty it up until January 31st
To learn more and get involved, click here!
If you have feedback or feature requests, I'd love to hear them. Let me know your number one complaint about HCB by replying to this email.
All the best,
Dylan & the HCB Team

We've put all the essential support links into a single support button at the bottom right of your screen. With just a click, you can contact us, leave feedback, or access our API docs and brand guidelines.
Also, be sure to visit our Help Center for tips, guides, and answers to FAQs---it's the best way to make the most of our features.
Transparency Mode has been one of HCB's flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. However, we've found that showcasing every transaction can sometimes mean extra housekeeping work for teams to keep the ledger tidy.
That's why we're excited to announce AI-powered memos for transactions!
Now, with 1-click, you can generate a transaction memo summarizing the receipt for any transaction. It's pretty simple:
Upload a receipt to a transaction.
Click the purple AI button to generate a memo.
Accept the suggestions by clicking the checkmark or pressing [enter].

You'll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt's contents.
As usual, we want to hear what you think!
As your fiscal sponsor, our mission is to empoweryour mission. This means helping you collect the donations that keep the lifeblood of your organization running.
As a result, we're introducing donations powered by Link. Link autofills your donors' payment details so they can easily complete their donation.
These simple, secure one-click payments are helping organizations grow their funds.
In addition to Link, we support Apple Pay, Google Pay, and good old-fashioned cards! 💳
All ACH transfers sent from HCB are now processed same-day!
That means, the moment an ACH is approved by HCB, it'll arrive that day (view the timing specifics). In most cases, this should cut the waiting time for an ACH from three business days to one.
You can now react to comments 😱! Show your thoughts instantly with a tap---whether it's a thumbs up, heart, or something else. Give it a try and add some fun to your conversations!

Exciting times are ahead for girls and nonbinary high school students at Hack Club.
Hack Club HQ is running four events in the next few months to empower girls and nonbinary students who code! All these events are running on HCB, using Transparency Mode. Each hackathon kicks off with a dinner featuring trailblazing women in tech.To learn more about these events and how to get involved, click here.
Golden hackathon, Bay Area, Sept 28th: workshops on Data Science, 3D Printing, and Web Development, with participants from Mission YoungArts, Home Away from Homelessness, and local schools.
Luna hackathon, New York City's Civic Hall, October 5th, with Girls Who Code on Web Development, Project Pitching, and Video Game Development with Sprig.
Celestial hackathon, Toronto, on October 19th at Shopify, will feature sessions on building PCBs, 3D modeling, and AI.
Ascend summit, Los Angeles, in mid-November, bringing together 50 girls and non-binary Hack Club leaders from around the world to code and meet mentors.

Transparency Mode has been one of HCB’s flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. However, we’ve found that showcasing every transaction can sometimes mean extra housekeeping work for teams to keep the ledger tidy.
That’s why we’re excited to announce AI-powered memos for transactions!
Now, with 1-click, you can generate a transaction memo summarizing the receipt for any transaction. It’s pretty simple:
You’ll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt’s contents.
As usual, we want to hear what you think!
There's nothing worse than checking for your card and realizing it's fallen out of your pocket. Now, when that happens, you can burn the card to cancel it and prevent any future transactions.
In the dark days of HCB, inviting people to your organization was always a binary risk assessment - "do I give this person unfettered access to everything, or nothing at all?"
Once we realized this was Suboptimal And A Bit Dangerous™️, we started to think about operational security from users' perspectives more carefully.
User roleswas step one. This introduced predetermined permission sets to control users' access in an organization.
Today,we're introducing spending controls. This allows managers of HCB organizations to impose a finer level of control on how much money a member can spend.
To get to a team member's spending controls page, visit the Team page and click on the$icon next to their name.
A team member's spending controls page gives you consolidated details of how they're using their cards.
When controls are disabled, a member can spend any amount of money with their cards. (Since they're not managers, so still can't transfer via ACH, check, HCB transfer, etc.)
With spending controls enabled, new transactions on Fiona's card will be approved/declined based on Fiona's balance. Since we haven't given her an allowance yet, her balance is zero! (as seen above)
Hint: click theNewbutton on the top right.
Now that I've given Fiona an allowance, she can spend it with her card! This $2,500 didn't leave the organization's balance when I created an allowance. Instead, both balances will decrease when she makes a purchase.
You should probably also know that these allowances are not time-dependent. They don't expire, and they do not recur (it's not a weekly/monthly limit).
As a convenience, you can also choose to enable spending controls and set an initial amount when you invite someone to your organization.

Hey folks - thanks for all great feedback on our recent reimbursements launch!
We’ve now made the peer review stage of the reimbursements flow optional. That means that you can choose whether or not other team members have to review a report submitted by a team member.
This setting can be found underReimbursementson your organization’s settings page.
Team reviews are still required for all reports submitted by external contributors.
👋 Hey everyone! Ever wanted to give out CUSTOM stickers for your organization/event? We're proud to announce that HCB has partnered with StickerNinja to offer all our fiscally sponsored organizations an exclusive 15% discount on sticker purchases made on their store!
This new perk can be found in the "Perks" tab of your HCB organization's dashboard. Send some custom stickers out into the 🌎!
Money’s great. If you’re reading this, you probably like money. Now, we’re making it easier than ever to get it.
Starting today, you can now process reimbursements for yourself, your team members, and your volunteers through HCB directly.
Looking to be reimbursed? Here's the process:
Compile a collection of expenses into a report on HCB.
Have your report reviewed by a team member and a HCB admin.
Get paid through ACH transfer or check.
You can try it out today in “Reimbursements” tab of your project.
Been using Expensify? We'll continue to process open reports; however, future reports should be made on HCB. We'll reach out soon with more details about offboarding from Expensify.
As your organization grows, so too does the number of people you invite to HCB. Today, we're handing you the keys to lock down critical actions to your most trusted team members.
When managing your team on HCB, you now have the choice of assigning users one of two roles:managerormember.
Managerscan do everything, just like everyone could before. This includes actions like editing your organization's settings, managing other users, and sending money (ACH, Check, HCB transfer, etc.).
Membershave limited permissions, but they can still spend money using their HCB card.
Our goal is to enhance security and provide you with the tools to grow your organization. Take it for a test drive by enabling the User Roles feature preview in your organization's settings. To learn more, see therolespage.
This feature has been highly requested, and we want to get it right. If you have feedback, please file it in the box at the bottom right of HCB.

One of HCB’s most commonly used features is making payments with physical cards. As usual, when receiving a physical card in the mail, follow the link provided in the instructions. You may notice that we require your card’s last 4 digits during the activation process.
If you’re trying to find one transaction in particular from a certain date, gone are the days of trying to guess the page number. Simply filter by date:

We at Hack Club HQ love to fill our HCB account's ledger with emojis and custom memos for each transaction. Recently, however, we've been falling behind due to the volume of transactions on the account.
Today, we've added a new feature preview ("Rename Transactions on the Ledger") that'll make renaming transactions a lot faster. After enabling it, head to your organization's homepage and double click on any transaction's memo. A text box will appear and you'll be able to add a custom memo right there on the homepage.
